message.content:
cs.CL, cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.IR, cs.NE 

This paper is about neural sequence-to-sequence models for abstractive text summarization, which falls under the category of natural language processing (NLP). Therefore, the most likely sub-category is cs.CL (Computation and Language). The paper also proposes a novel architecture that uses pointer-generator networks, which involves generating new words and copying words from the source text, and coverage to avoid repetition. These techniques are related to machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI), which makes cs.LG (Machine Learning) and cs.AI (Artificial Intelligence) likely sub-categories as well. The paper also evaluates its model using the ROUGE metric, which is commonly used in information retrieval (IR) and text summarization tasks, making cs.IR (Information Retrieval) a possible sub-category. Finally, the paper's use of neural networks suggests that cs.NE (Neural and Evolutionary Computing) could also be a relevant sub-category.
